Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186,.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14 states that tenants have the right to a dwelling free from mold infestations that substantially endanger their health or safety and require prompt remediation by the landlord.

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Defendant's failure to address the mold infestation and provide habitable living conditions constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent) recognizes that Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law should abandon caveat emptor and impose an implied obligation on landlords to provide dwelling units that meet minimum statutory/sanitary standards, and that the tenant’s rent obligation is mutually dependent on the landlord’s performance. While the excerpt focuses on State Sanitary Code violations generally, not mold specifically, it supports the broader proposition that failure to maintain habitable conditions in violation of the Code breaches an implied warranty of habitability under Massachusetts law. The covenant of quiet enjoyment is not discussed in this excerpt, so support is only clear as to the implied warranty of habitability, not quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant's failure to address the mold infestation and provide habitable living conditions constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case directly holds that a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions—here, repeated flooding with water and sewage in violation of the State Sanitary Code—constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. While the facts involve flooding rather than mold specifically, the reasoning is about unsanitary, uninhabitable conditions generally, so it supports the proposition that failure to correct serious habitability defects (such as mold) can breach both the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt:
“We have held that every landlord that rents residential property warrants to its tenants that the premises will be delivered and maintained in a habitable condition… A landlord’s breach of this duty abates the tenant’s obligation to pay rent… Further, a landlord that fails to maintain a habitable dwelling for its tenant is liable for resulting personal injuries…
…Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

G.L. c. 186, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14 states that tenants have the right to a dwelling free from mold infestations that substantially endanger their health or safety and require prompt remediation by the landlord.

Berman & Sons v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 19.proposition: Defendant's failure to address the mold infestation and provide habitable living conditions constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Berman & Sons v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 19.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide adequate heat and hot water is a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability under Massachusetts law and allows rent abatement regardless of landlord fault. However, the opinion does not address mold or discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment; its analysis is confined to the warranty of habitability and rent abatement for heat and hot water failures. Thus it supports only part of the proposition, and not the specific mold or quiet-enjoyment aspects.
Berman & Sons v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 19.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition… We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

Lawrence v. Anglo American Real Estate,.raw_text: Lawrence v. Anglo American Real Estate, 208 Mass. App. Ct. 736 (2011)
Lawrence v. Anglo American Real Estate,.proposition: Defendant's failure to address the mold infestation and provide habitable living conditions constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.

Kargman v. Linski, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 45.raw_text: Kargman v. Linski, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 45 (1983)
Kargman v. Linski, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 45.proposition: Defendant's failure to address the mold infestation and provide habitable living conditions constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Kargman v. Linski, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 45.support_reasoning: The case concerns limited partners’ obligations to make capital contributions under the Uniform Limited Partnership Act and does not involve residential tenancies, habitability standards, mold, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It addresses partnership law and investors’ remedies against general partners, not landlord-tenant law or the implied warranty of habitability under Massachusetts law. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about mold and habitability breaches.
Kargman v. Linski, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 45.relevant_excerpt: “Relatively little case law has developed under ULPA... We have remarked, however, the affinity of purpose between the limited partnership and the business corporation. The status of a limited partner as analogous to that of a stockholder has not gone unnoted by courts and commentators.... It is appropriate, therefore, to look to cases involving stock subscriptions for assistance in measuring the extent of obligation of a subscriber to a limited partnership.”

G.L. c. 111, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 186, Section 14 states that tenants have the right to a dwelling free from mold infestations that substantially endanger their health or safety and require prompt remediation by the landlord.

Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass..raw_text: Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994)
Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass..proposition: Defendant's failure to address the mold infestation and provide habitable living conditions constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass..support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that serious code violations and uncorrected conditions (lack of heat and hot water, vermin infestation, etc.) constitute both a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. However, the opinion does not mention mold or mold infestation specifically; it deals with other substandard conditions. Thus it supports the general legal principle that failure to maintain habitable conditions can breach the warranty and covenant, but not specifically as to mold infestation.
Cruz Management Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “From May, 1988, through October, 1990 … conditions in the apartment violated numerous provisions of the State Sanitary Code. The apartment lacked adequate heat and hot water, and was infested with cockroaches, mice and rats…. The judge found that conditions during the relevant period ‘were such so as to make the premises of no value to [Thomas].’ … Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”
